title: 104_hr2727
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Congressional Responsibility Act of 1995" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The "Congressional Responsibility Act of 1995" aims to ensure that Federal regulations are only enacted by Congress, as outlined in Section 2 of the Act. This will prevent unelected officials from the executive branch from making regulations without Congressional approval, promoting a more democratic and accountable process. SEC. 3. ENACTMENT OF AGENCY REGULATIONS. Regulations cannot take effect without Congressional approval through a bill containing the regulation's text. Agencies must submit a report to Congress with the proposed regulation text and an explanation of its basis and purpose. (a) Introduction.--Within three legislative days of an agency submitting a report under section 3(b), the Majority Leader of each House of Congress must introduce a bill containing the regulation text. If the bill is not introduced, any Member of that House may do so.
(b) Bill.--A bill under this section refers to a bill in Congress that approves agency regulations, with the regulation text specified after the enacting clause.
(c) Referral and Consideration.--Such bills do not need to be referred to a committee, and any Member of the House can move for consideration. The agency regulations are approved as law. Bills approving regulations do not need committee referral and any Member can move for consideration. The motion is privileged and not debatable, amendable, or subject to postponement. The motion to consider the bill is highly privileged, not debatable, and not subject to amendment or postponement. If agreed to, the respective House will immediately proceed to consider the bill without interruption. Debate on the bill and related motions is limited to one hour, divided equally between supporters and opponents. Debate on the bill and related motions is limited to one hour, divided equally between supporters and opponents. An amendment to the bill is not allowed, and motions to postpone or reconsider the vote are not in order. Appeals from the Chair's decisions on procedural matters are decided without debate. A motion to reconsider the vote on a bill is not allowed. Appeals from the Chair's decisions on procedural matters are decided without debate. Final passage of a bill must occur within 60 days of its introduction. A motion to suspend certain rules can be passed with a majority vote. A motion to suspend subsections (c) and (d) of a bill can be passed with a majority vote in Congress. If both Houses receive bills with the same text, the bill from the other House will not be referred to a committee and can only be considered for final passage. The procedure in the receiving House will be the same for the bill. Upon receiving a bill from the other House with the same text, it will not be referred to a committee and can only be considered for final passage. The procedure in the receiving House will be the same as if no bill had been received, but the vote on final passage will be on the bill from the other House. Once the bill from the other House is dealt with, the bill originating in the receiving House cannot be considered. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines "agency" and "regulation" in accordance with existing laws. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act applies to agency regulations made after its enactment. SEC. 7. JUDICIAL REVIEW. Regulations in bills under this Act are not subject to judicial review as agency actions.
